awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Just Connect Us: A Community-Oriented Civil Justice Data Commons
awd_abstract_narration:
In the United States, cities are increasingly connected through a digital infrastructure that integrates services with the lives of their residents. These systems make cities “smart” by producing real-time data to manage services efficiently and promote the well-being of residents.  This project extends this model to the courts, legal service providers, and administrative agencies that make up a community’s civil justice system.  These institutions assist residents with legal problems like housing, debt, child custody, and public benefits. But, despite their centrality in people’s lives, they are neither “smart” nor “connected.” Currently, data from courts, legal service providers, and administrative agencies are collected in multiple formats and housed among multiple institutions. Access to these data, moreover, is governed by a hodgepodge of statutes, regulations, and rules. As a consequence, researchers and policymakers do not know whether the justice system furthers people’s well-being.  This project investigates what rules and data standards will facilitate the sharing of data by civil justice institutions in a data commons to produce knowledge about how well these institutions serve people and what their long-term effects are on people’s lives.

This project adopts a two-pronged approach to design a civil justice data commons. It will engage with civil justice stakeholders in several communities to understand their interests and concerns. What incentives exist to share data? What privacy concerns arise? The second prong involves engaging with academic data scientists about the technical requirements and best practices for the creation of a viable data commons in the civil justice field, learning from the development of data commons in other areas (e.g., biomedical data science; social survey research).  By developing best practices for data management and sharing among community civil justice institutions, this planning study will encourage state and county courts, legal service providers, government labs, and policy institutes to take steps towards building a civil justice data commons in their communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Smart communities are typically connected through a digital infrastructure that allows for the coordination and integration of municipal services into residents’ lives. This planning study investigated how local civil justice ecosystems could become smart and connected in the same way. Courts, legal services providers, and administrative agencies deal with residents’ debt, housing, public benefits, child custody, and other legal problems. This study considered how data generated in this ecosystem could be collected, harmonized, and shared for academic, public policy, and operational research on the functioning of the civil justice system.

Every year, the court system adjudicates millions of cases involving poor and middle-income people, with enormous consequences for their housing security, family stability, and financial and overall wellbeing. Yet, despite the importance of courts in people’s lives, we know little about how they dispense justice or how entanglements in civil legal problems affect peoples’ lives. Currently, local civil justice systems are neither smart nor connected. Data from courts, legal services providers, and administrative agencies are collected in multiple formats under a variety of incompatible taxonomies and housed among multiple institutions. This results in a data infrastructure ill-equipped to help researchers and policymakers understand the operation of the civil justice system and its effects on the people who cycle through it. 

This project had substantial intellectual merit. Focusing on four distinct civil justice ecosystems, we documented what incentives existed for courts, legal services providers, and other civil justice stakeholders to become connected through the collection and sharing of data for research and analysis and what barriers impeded them. We also investigated whether a data commons – a safe and secure repository to manage and make available for research sensitive data – would facilitate research on the civil justice system. Developed in the life sciences fields, data commons allow researchers to access data for study in a secure environment that protects the privacy of data subjects and minimizes misuse of the data. This study explored whether the same model would work in the civil justice context to facilitate research on courts and other civil justice institutions.

We interviewed 32 representatives of courts, legal service providers, and nonpartisan research institutes from four civil justice communities – Cuyahoga County, Ohio; Oklahoma; Washington D.C.; and Wisconsin – and dozens of civil justice stakeholders from other jurisdictions to understand incentives for and impediments to sharing civil justice data for research. We also documented the regulatory framework for sharing data in each of the jurisdictions, met with data repository experts in other fields, and conducted an extensive literature review of data repository frameworks and the data commons landscape.

Our research yielded important findings. It showed that civil justice stakeholders were very interested in sharing data to yield knowledge about the civil justice system, but significant impediments made data sharing difficult. In particular, organizations had limited resources to capture, manage, and share data.  Data were often collected using incompatible classification schema. Court rules and other regulations also impeded data sharing. We found that sector-wide guidance and new rules and policies could facilitate data collection and sharing. Our research also showed that a data commons, built on a secure infrastructure and governed by a robust contractual regime, would alleviate many of the difficulties that attend data sharing to produce knowledge about the civil justice system. In particular, a data commons could play a central role in documenting, normalizing, and harmonizing data, prepare them for use in research and analysis, and make them available through a secure interface. In addition, housing the data commons at a trusted third-party intermediary, such as an academic institution, would allow for oversight of the conduct of participants and prevent data use contrary to data common rules. 

Our research had significant broader impacts. It resulted in one book chapter and two reports. It also led to foundation grant awards to create a civil justice data commons prototype – the Georgetown Civil Justice Data Commons – to facilitate data sharing by courts and use of court data for academic, policy, and court research. This work also included collaboration with a commercial technology company to design the interfaces and infrastructure of the data commons. Five post-doc fellows and numerous law and undergraduate research assistants received training during the course of the grant.
